question: What is the organic linker ligand that makes up the HUMs?
What are the three inorganic pillar ligands used in the HUMs?
What is the highest C2H2 uptake observed at 298 K and 1 bar?
What is the kinetic diameter of C2H2 and CO2?
What is the IAST selectivity (SAC) for SIFSIX-21-Ni at 1 bar and 298 K with a 1:1 C2H2/CO2 gas mixture?
What is the (ΔQst)AC value for SIFSIX-21-Ni at half loading?
If all six HUMs exhibited strong binding sites for C2H2 and weaker affinity for CO2, would you expect the C2H2 uptake to be higher than the CO2 uptake?
Given that SIFSIX-21-Ni showed the highest C2H2 uptake, would you expect it to have the strongest binding sites for C2H2 compared to the other HUMs?

The text mentions that traditional physisorbents like zeolites and activated carbons exhibit poor selectivity for C2H2 over CO2 due to similar physicochemical properties. If a new physisorbent material is developed with significantly different physicochemical properties compared to C2H2 and CO2, would you expect it to potentially have better selectivity for C2H2 over CO2?
The HUMs are composed of organic and inorganic linker ligands. Would you say that HUMs are a subclass of MOMs?

The paper states that narrow pore sizes in HUMs can limit surface area and uptake capacity. If a new HUM is synthesized with larger pore sizes, would you expect its surface area and uptake capacity to potentially be higher?

The article mentions that the C2H2/CO2 separation selectivity (αAC) values for equimolar mixtures have been experimentally measured for only 16 sorbents. If a new sorbent material is tested for C2H2/CO2 separation selectivity under equimolar conditions, would the total number of sorbents with experimentally measured αAC values increase?
The text states that the HUM sorbents require heating to only 333 K for regeneration. Based on this information, would a higher temperature be required for regeneration of HUM sorbents?
All HUMs are composed of inorganic pillar ligands, organic linker ligands, and two metal cations.
The six HUMs were synthesized using the same organic linker ligand.
SIFSIX-21-Ni had the lowest C2H2 uptake among the six HUMs studied.
The study found that IAST selectivities for C2H2/CO2 separation were higher at 2 bar compared to 1 bar.
The adsorption capacity of SIFSIX-21-Ni was less than 3.5 mmol/g.
The binding sites for CO2 in SIFSIX-21-Ni involve interactions with the nitrogen atoms of the organic linker ligand.
The synthesis of NbOFFIVE-3-Ni and NbOFFIVE-3-Cu involved the use of nickel and copper salts, respectively.
